properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Cheltenham, Moorabbin. 

  • There is a factory fire on Hewitt Street, Cheltenham.
  • The fire is not yet under control.
  • The smoke is traveling in a northeasterly direction, towards South Road. 
Anyone located in the surrounding area should take shelter indoors immediately. 

What you should do:

  • Close all exterior doors and windows.
  • Turn off heating and cooling systems.
  • Close fireplaces and vents.
  • You should avoid the area. 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
  • If you are driving, close the windows in your vehicle and turn off the air conditioning.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The following road is closed: Keys Road, between Chesterville Road and Warrigal Road.
  • Traffic in the area may be affected.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

The next update is expected by 16/04/2023 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Smoke information:

  • Smoke can affect peopleâ€™s health.
  • People with heart or lung conditions (including asthma), children, pregnant women and older people are more sensitive to the effects of breathing in smoke.
  • People with existing heart or lung conditions (including asthma) should follow the treatment plan advised by the doctor.
Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - STRUCTURE FIRE - Stay Indoors
Incident Location: Hewitt Street, Cheltenham
Issue Date: Sunday 16 April 2023, 03:56 pm
Next Update: Sunday 16 April 2023, 06:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/29246/moreinfo

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Cheltenham, Moorabbin. 

- There is a factory fire on Hewitt Street, Cheltenham. 
- The fire is not yet under control.
- The smoke is traveling in a northeasterly direction, towards South Road. 


Anyone located in the surrounding area should take shelter indoors immediately.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Kyneton, Malmsbury, Woodleigh Heights, Drummond North, Kyneton South, Lauriston
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for water quality at Kyneton and Malmsbury.
  • This updates the Advice issued at 4:51pm on 14 April 2023.
  • The tap water at Kyneton and Malmsbury is not safe to drink without boiling first.
  • On 11 April, a burst water main on Rennick Avenue, Kyneton resulted in a water supply interruption and may have compromised the safety of the drinking water.
  • Coliban Water has repaired the burst water main, however, it must be boiled before drinking until Coliban Water confirms that it is safe to drink.
  • Flushing was completed on 13 April and sampling continues in both towns. 
  • For further updates, visit www.coliban.com.au/interruptions
If you live or work within Kyneton and Malmsbury, you must boil tap water before drinking. 
What you should do:   
  • Boil water before drinking it or drink bottled water.
  • Boil water for food preparation, preparing beverages, washing and preparing food, making ice, preparing baby formula and brushing teeth. 
  • Unboiled water can be used for washing your hands, showering and bathing, flushing toilets, washing dishes (ensure dry before use) and clothes and watering your garden. Ensure water is not ingested whilst bathing. 
To ensure water is safe to drink: 
  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switches are suitable).  
  • Allow water to cool before use.  
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use.
Caution should be taken to prevent scalding from boiling water. 

If you are concerned you may have been affected by contaminated water, contact your doctor or call Nurse-on-Call 1300 60 60 24 (24 hours, seven days).
Impacts in your area:
  • Drinking water trailers are now available at the Kyneton Showgrounds and opposite the Malmsbury Botanical Gardens on Ellesmere Place.
  • Kyneton and Malmsbury residents will be able to fill suitable containers to supplement their home drinking water supply.
  • The standpipe located in Kyneton has been isolated until further notice.
This message was issued by the Department of Health.

Next update is expected by 16/04/2023 5:00pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.  

Accessibility:  
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - WATER QUALITY Incident Location: Kyneton, Malmsbury Issue Date: Saturday 15 April 2023, 03:00 pm Next Update: Sunday 16 April 2023, 05:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/29237/moreinfo This Advice is being issued for water quality at Kyneton and Malmsbury. - This updates the Advice issued at 4:51pm on 14 April 2023. - The tap water at Kyneton and Malmsbury is not safe to drink without boiling first. - On 11 April, a burst water main on Rennick Avenue, Kyneton resulted in a water supply interruption and may have compromised the safety of the drinking water. - Coliban Water has repaired the burst water main, however, it must be boiled before drinking until Coliban Water confirms that it is safe to drink. - Flushing was completed on 13 April and sampling continues in both towns. - For further updates, visit www.coliban.com.au/interruptions If you live or work within Kyneton and Malmsbury, you must boil tap water before drinking.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Watts River.

The Watts River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 58 mm since 09:00 AM Saturday 15 April 2023. Rainfall totals of 1 to 5 mm are forecast for the catchment for Sunday 16 April 2023.

Water levels of the Yarra River and Watts Rivers at various locations are rising in response to the rain.

Watts River:

The level of the Watts River at Healesville is currently peaking at 1.82 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (2.80 metres).

Minor flooding in the Yarra/Watts River catchment is expected to affect low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/04/2023 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Yarra River from Millgrove to Coldstream
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Yarra River from Millgrove to Coldstream.

The Yarra River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 43 mm in the upper part of the catchment and about 44 mm in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Saturday 15 April 2023. Rainfall totals of 1 to 5 mm are forecast for the catchment for Sunday 16 April 2023.

Water levels of the Yarra River and Watts Rivers at various locations are rising in response to the rain.

Yarra River from Millgrove to Coldstream:

The level of the Yarra River at Coldstream is currently at 2.02 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (4.00 metre) and rising. It is expected to peak near the Minor Flood Level tomorrow afternoon (Monday 17th April 2023).

There is some potential for Minor flooding in the Yarra River catchment to affect low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 
Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with the affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing, or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake..
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae.
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however, care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 27/04/2023 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Monday 03 April 2023, 11:58 am
Next Update: Thursday 27 April 2023, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/29194/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
- High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with the affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing, or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbotsford
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbotsford.

The level of the Yarra River at Templestowe is currently at 1.55 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (3.50 metres) and rising again. It has peaked once at 1.72 metres and will peak again this evening (Sunday 16th April 2023) below Minor Flood Level.

The level of the Yarra River at Heidelberg is currently at 3.74 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (6.00 metres) and falling. It has peaked once at 4.48 metres and will peak again tonight (Sunday 16th April 2023) below the Minor Flood Level.

The level of the Yarra River at Alphington is currently at 1.28 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (3.00 metres) and rising. It is expected to peak below the Minor Flood Level later this evening (Sunday 16th April 2023).

The level of the Yarra River at Abbotsford is currently at 2.08 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (2.70 metres) and falling. It peaked at 2.49 metres earlier this morning (Sunday 16th April 2023).

There is some potential for Minor flooding in the Yarra River catchment to affect low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/04/2023 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
